text: Number 430, Samuel M. Atkinson, et al., Petitioners, versus Sinclair Refining Company.

Before the recess, I had indicated that the District Court had dismissed Count II of the complaint that is the action against the individual local officials and Count III of the complaint, request for the injunction.
No, I'm talking about the employer's requested injunction --
Against all the defendants, labor organizations, individuals, their agents, counselors, servants, etcetera.
Is the arbitration provisions -- are they comparable to those in Lincoln Mills?
The arbitration provisions set out a grievance procedure.

I -- I don't want this -- disturb the train of your argument but I -- it would help me if -- if I knew precisely what issues were before the arbitrator at the time this suit in the District Court was filed by the employer.

The employer after the work stoppage occurred docked the local union committeemen for the time of the work stoppage claiming that they were not fulfilling their responsibilities as local union officials.
Joint agreement and arbitrator has not been selected as yet.
I guess that's the thing (Voice Overlap) --
Could -- could the union go into court to get an injunction against the employer that may lock-out and directing the employer to arbitrate?
I would say this that under our arguments relating to Norris-LaGuardia Act, that so long as the Norris-LaGuardia Act is still vital, it covers all areas of labor disputes.
That -- then what is the -- what is the total purport then of -- of Lincoln Mills?
Well, I think this, Your Honor, that Lincoln Mills demonstrates that the parties have available to them a multitude of remedies which they can agree to.
I think that the injunction of the court would be restricted to directing the employer to -- to arbitrate.
At this point, yes sir, if the lockout is to be considered the same as the strike.
I'm sorry to back track a little bit.
I would say this Your Honor that the commitment regarding the lockout runs to the union.
This is my view of the subject.
This is my view of the subject.
There is no grievance procedure but there's no-lockout --
I think it is the responsibility of the unions to bring that suit.
Do you think an individual employee could not bring a suit?
Well, if the union hasn't been locked out, the employees have been locked out.
And this fellow says, "I've been locked out and I'm not suing for wages.
I submit, Mr. Justice Stewart, that the no-lockout pledge runs to the contracting party and the contracting party in this case is the organization.
Well, could this -- could -- could an employee bring this suit in the federal courts under Section 301?
I can't see how Your Honor, because Section 301 provides for only suits between employers and --
It doesn't say who shall bring them or who -- who shall be the plaintiffs or who shall be the defendant?

Well, I would say this, Your Honor, that in this -- the way I would interpret the import of Section 301 is that if an individual brought a suit for breach of the collective bargaining contract, unless the individuals made a party to the collective bargaining contract, he doesn't have sta -- stature to be a party to that lawsuit.
Would this matter standing be something which the Federal District Court should refer to state law to determine the answer to it?
As -- I would -- I'm not sure I understand your question, Your Honor.
You say -- I think you said he didn't have stature and I suppose --
Is this a question of federal law?
As to whether or not he is a party to the collective --
Well, I think the federal courts could make a determination whether the individual is a party to the collective bargaining contract.
I -- I think I'm right in saying that the statute doesn't, certainly by its terms, specify who the plaintiff needs to be.
-- if he had been locked out by an employer who would sign a collective bargaining agreement saying he would not lockout his employees.

My answer would have to remain, Your Honor that if an individual brought a suit for breach of the collective bargaining contract, the first question that would have to be asked, "Are you a party to the collective bargaining contract?"
Yes, but he -- I would say this that he is not bringing a suit for breach of the collective bargaining contract.
Well, I think we're -- I've alleged a little appeal but I -- I was just testing out the first part of your argument that no suit could be ever be brought against individuals.

I would say this, Your Honor that I think that'd be very, very unfortunate if the courts were to interpret Section 301 as to allow individual union members to flood the federal courts with suits of breaches of collective bargaining contracts.

-- suppose -- suppose underlying all these was the refusal of the union to arbitrate, I suppose that you would agree that the injunction would run to the union requiring it to arbitrate, assuming that the agreement provided for it, the collective bargaining agreement.
Oh, there's no question, Mr. Justice Douglas that the employer has the right to bring the union in the court and ask for a specific performance of arbitration.
But the question of whether or not these work stoppages occurred and the unions can be held in contempt of court because they occur is another matter.
But in terms of the -- of power of contempt, I suppose that would be implicit in the -- if the court had the power to issue an injunction, directing union to arbitrate and the union didn't arbitrate.
-- over any work stoppages that occur.

You -- your type of injunction if you think would be proper and the only one as concerns the union would be one that directed the union to arbitrate and held the union responsible for the things that happened --
-- during the period when the arbitration was supposed to be going on that might fairly be said to be an indirect method of defeating arbitration.
This would be at a formal union meeting clearly.
The thing -- the point would be this, Mr. Justice Brennan, that say the employees still insisted on striking, the union issues a telegram --
Well, Mr. Justice Brennan, I think that there would be problems in Norris-LaGuardia.

I would say this, Your Honor, that if we were to say that a court could make a determination if they threatened, breach of the contract was legal or illegal the court certainly has that power to do so.
Well that is a declaratory judgment as to whether or not the union is about to threaten a breach of the contract.

I would say this that the -- under the Norris-LaGuardia Act, I would suggest that the farthest the court could go under that situation would be a declaratory judgment of some kind as to whether or not a threatened strike was in breach of collective bargaining contract.
Well, we again get back to the question of who we -- who the court would be restraining.
I -- I presume what you are saying is that you do not think 301 repeal the Norris-LaGuardia Act in whole or in part?
I -- I thought you've said that you did agree that it at least repeal that in part as far as the injunction went to the union.

Oh, not Section 301 but the Taft-Hartley Act has repealed it in many instances where you can get restraining orders against unions for breach as a secondary boycotts and another type of activities with the --
Under 301 I understood you to say that an injunction, an issue against the union requiring it to arbitrate.
Well, I -- I submit, Your Honor, that that term was not used by me but by the court.
I don't suggest that this is an injunction and I think in Lincoln Mills, it was made clear that a specific performance did not fall within the purview of injunctions under Norris-LaGuardia.
Well, that would be a -- that -- that then takes something out from what is in Norris-LaGuardia prior to 301.
Well, Norris-LaGuardia contains specific provision encouraging the use of arbitration and this was referred to in Lincoln Mills.
You want -- you want your cake and you want to eat it, too.
If it please the Court, I would like to apologize for not being here on time this morning.
I was somewhat doubtful at times as to what case Mr. Cornfield was arguing.
Well, I think its in -- inherent, Your Honor, because the contract provides any grievances must.
No more than -- than any plaintiff is compelled to present any claim.
Well, we could compel them in what we are seeking as to establish a procedure by indirection to compel --
Well, what I got at is, could you make -- may assume specific requirements of arbitration (Inaudible)
-- not to strike and if they have anything they --
If they wished to progress one of these grievances.
Of course the fact that is -- that is (Inaudible)
There is no doubt about it, whatsoever.
Well, I don't think that is so unusual, Your Honor, and I think you will find a substantially similar framework.
I gather the factor that this is -- they did file (Inaudible)

At page 118 of the record (Inaudible) the question for whom you're talking about (Inaudible) the matter to decide of course, that's the question (Inaudible) does the matters involve (Inaudible) pending arbitration and they decided to filed to an arbitrator pending to hear the appeals, could such grievance can be made against (Inaudible)?
That's not 118, pages in my record says --
I'm using it in the sense, Your Honor they can compel us to arbitrate.
And I am thinking always in the terminology that the fellow who brings the grievance is the employer or his agent because the management has the right to make the working decision.
Clearly, that Mr. Christensen, I gather the Court of Appeals at least, you asked alternatively in any event for declaratory judgment, didn't you?
Well, what does the Court of Appeals had referenced to?
Your Honor, with due respect to the Court of Appeals, I don't understand that anymore than you.
-- reference to the fact that there was no live grievances, did it?

Apparently, I -- I don't know, but we were faced with this problem when we sought to come here, that we wanted certiorari granted and we didn't want to bring up too many questions and we brought up only the injunction question on our petition.
Then this matter of declaratory judgment is out of the case?
That's out of the case here.
Mr. Christensen, that second count of your rest only on diversity of course, doesn't it?
It is so stated, it need not -- it need --
What -- what -- what law would it to apply on the matter, the substantive claim?
We proceeded on the theory that we would go upon -- upon state law.
You have a claim in the first count which is not before us I gather, it's still to be tried.
And that's plainly federal law, isn't it?
You suggest as against the individuals, are these individuals officers or whatever?
Well, in that sense, they are --
So you're suing them in their representative capacity, aren't you?
Not in the sense that by suing them we are binding the organization.
Well, are you -- are you suing them as individuals allegedly who did things as union committeemen?
Yes, having the powers of union leadership, they did these things and were able to exercise an influence on leading people out.
But why -- why isn't that then suing in a representative capacity?
Well, it -- it -- I think it is.
But you suggest that state law can govern that claim whereas federal law would govern the claim against the union as such.
I -- I am not at all sure, Justice, that we are correct about that.
Well if that so, I suppose it's possible then to say that since we have 301 then that obviously contemplates actions only against labor organizations.
I -- the answer to a question saying conceivably has to be yes.

Now, you -- you're -- you're faced basically with the proposition, are you going to hold that -- that a collective contract containing a no-strike clause is binding upon the employees who were the beneficiaries of it.
Well, you have to agree that Congress certainly wanted, in an act in 301, to make very clear that Danbury Hatters was no longer law.
Because we get -- we get only a judgment against men that we can prove participated, not a Danbury Hatters whole conspiracy thing where you bring him in and they're responsible for everything.
Well, is that -- that you asked for a judgment jointly and separately against the individual defendant.
(Voice Overlap) 5000 suppose that would be, what (Inaudible)
No, no we don't say a awful lot of people to show up for work.
Alright, put it that way then, they might have got 5000 people afterwards.
Sir, and the sum of money -- the sum of money rises only with the evil of their own conduct.
Can you tell me quickly Mr. Cornfield, is it your view that there were no live grievances that did everything that involved in this the way the grievances has been resolved in arbitration?
-- there are still the grievance spending regarding the -- the counties against --
That's all I -- that's all I want to know.
